          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;

          }

            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {

          }

            width: 100%;

            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;

        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          }
          mr-issue-metadata {
            min-width: auto;
            max-width: auto;
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            min-height: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
          mr-issue-metadata, .issue-header-container {
            position: static;
          }
        }

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

          Note:<b>Note:</b>
          Clock icons indicate that users may not be available.
          Tooltips show the reason.
          <div id="message"><!---->
          <b>Note:</b>
          Clock icons indicate that users may not be available.
          Tooltips show the reason.

Open in Chrome the attached file test.txt which is <2MB<span class="line"><!---->1. Open in Chrome the attached file test.txt which is &lt;2MB<!----></span><br>2. Observe memory usage climbs to 9GB commit, 4GB working set<span class="line"><!---->2. Observe memory usage climbs to 9GB commit, 4GB working set<!----></span><br>3. Scratch your head<span class="line"><!---->3. Scratch your head<!----></span><br><br>What is the expected behavior?<span class="line"><!---->What is the expected behavior?<!----></span><br>Chrome shouldn't eat so much memory.<span class="line"><!---->Chrome shouldn't eat so much memory.<!----></span><br><br>What went wrong?<span class="line"><!---->What went wrong?<!----></span><br>I opened a bunch of CI tabs in raw log format and Windows gave me a low memory notice and random processes started crashing including Chrome.<span class="line"><!---->I opened a bunch of CI tabs in raw log format and Windows gave me a low memory notice and random processes started crashing including Chrome.<!----></span><br><br>Did this work before? N/A <span class="line"><!---->Did this work before? N/A <!----></span><br><br>Chrome version: 88.0.4324.150  Channel: stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome version: 88.0.4324.150  Channel: stable<!----></span><br>OS Version: 6.1 (Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2)<span class="line"><!---->OS Version: 6.1 (Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2)<!----></span><br>Flash Version: <span class="line"><!---->Flash Version: <!----></span><br><br>I was able to reproduce the large memory usage but not the crash from a clean profile. See attached screenshot.<span class="line"><!---->I was able to reproduce the large memory usage but not the crash from a clean profile. See attached screenshot.<!----></span><br><br>The test.txt is a raw log from curl CI builds:<span class="line"><!---->The test.txt is a raw log from curl CI builds:<!----></span><br>https://github.com/curl/curl/runs/1900860438<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/curl/curl/runs/1900860438"><!---->https://github.com/curl/curl/runs/1900860438<!----></a><br>https://dev.azure.com/daniel0244/5571c33c-81e1-43d7-93ee-d3d4152f27b2/_apis/build/builds/4719/logs/110<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://dev.azure.com/daniel0244/5571c33c-81e1-43d7-93ee-d3d4152f27b2/_apis/build/builds/4719/logs/110"><!---->https://dev.azure.com/daniel0244/5571c33c-81e1-43d7-93ee-d3d4152f27b2/_apis/build/builds/4719/logs/110<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Probably you did reproduce, your host or VM just has limited memory that's why it didn't grow so high. I am able to reproduce in Windows 7 and Windows 10 VMs using Chrome/88.0.4324.150. Since the VMs have limited memory the memory usage the usage doesn't grow as high before Chrome and/or some system processes crash. See the animated GIF taken in a windows 7 vm.<span class="line"><!---->Probably you did reproduce, your host or VM just has limited memory that's why it didn't grow so high. I am able to reproduce in Windows 7 and Windows 10 VMs using Chrome/88.0.4324.150. Since the VMs have limited memory the memory usage the usage doesn't grow as high before Chrome and/or some system processes crash. See the animated GIF taken in a windows 7 vm.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I checked, the file has all of its text in a giant <pre> element, so the html tree size is actually very small. I logged this locally and the visible_objects is 1, so this does not appear to be from TextPaintTimingDetector. FWIW I do see 2GB memory footprint.<span class="line"><!---->I checked, the file has all of its text in a giant &lt;pre&gt; element, so the html tree size is actually very small. I logged this locally and the visible_objects is 1, so this does not appear to be from TextPaintTimingDetector.         I did a bisect with memory-infra tracing on MacOS:<span class="line"><!---->I did a bisect with memory-infra tracing on MacOS:<!----></span><br><br>You are probably looking for a change made after 731060 (known good), but no later than 731077 (first known bad).<span class="line"><!---->You are probably looking for a change made after 731060 (known good), but no later than 731077 (first known bad).<!----></span><br>CHANGELOG URL:<span class="line"><!---->CHANGELOG URL:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+log/39d1df5013f8f3ea61d06c40dd692d256105fa33..8f6de08a2a1dd1451183effcf5baad9f5424a0d9<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+log/39d1df5013f8f3ea61d06c40dd692d256105fa33..8f6de08a2a1dd1451183effcf5baad9f5424a0d9"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+log/39d1df5013f8f3ea61d06c40dd692d256105fa33..8f6de08a2a1dd1451183effcf5baad9f5424a0d9<!----></a><br><br><br>which is probably this about reporting, so not sure how useful that was:<span class="line"><!---->which is probably this about reporting, so not sure how useful that was:<!----></span><br><br>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/96e1d87a75e82ee47bbb2034ececed92e7760435<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/96e1d87a75e82ee47bbb2034ececed92e7760435"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/96e1d87a75e82ee47bbb2034ececed92e7760435<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        On Windows, using Visual Studio heap debugging and taking snapshots for a 10 line excerpt of the log file, then loading a longer version that contains the first block of "test data^@test data...", it seems like private bytes increases, but the actual heap snapshot difference between two snapshots is not that big. I am not an expert at memory debugging but this may mean that there have been a lot of temporary allocations trying to line break the "test data^@" blocks?" (and this is a build with partition_alloc enabled, so visual studio's insight into what's happening with the allocations may be limited).<span class="line"><!---->On Windows, using Visual Studio heap debugging and taking snapshots for a 10 line excerpt of the log file, then loading a longer version that contains the first block of "test data^@test data...", it seems like private bytes increases, but the actual heap snapshot difference between two snapshots is not that big. I am not an expert at memory debugging but this may mean that there have been a lot of temporary allocations trying to line break the "test data^@" blocks?" (and this is a build with partition_alloc enabled, so visual studio's insight into what's happening with the allocations may be limited).<!----></span><br><br>Between the heap snapshots, most of the allocations (third column, bytes) are in:<span class="line"><!---->Between the heap snapshots, most of the allocations (third column, bytes) are in:<!----></span><br>cc::ProxyMain::BeginMainFrame	77,462	9,047,361	cc.dll<span class="line"><!---->cc::ProxyMain::BeginMainFrame	77,462	9,047,361	cc.dll<!----></span><br>cc::LayerTreeHost::RequestMainFrameUpdate	62,881	6,921,069	cc.dll<span class="line"><!---->cc::LayerTreeHost::RequestMainFrameUpdate	62,881	6,921,069	cc.dll<!----></span><br>cc::LayerTreeHost::BeginMainFrame	14,560	2,024,744	cc.dll<span class="line"><!---->cc::LayerTreeHost::BeginMainFrame	14,560	2,024,744	cc.dll<!----></span><br><br>Which in itself does not look excessive. <span class="line"><!---->Which in itself does not look excessive. <!----></span><br><br>A second important observation: I see a big difference in heap memory consumption if I create a log file where I remove the test data^@ lines. <span class="line"><!---->A second important observation: I see a big difference in heap memory consumption if I create a log file where I remove the test data^@ lines. <!----></span><br><br>With longlog4.txt (attached) where I remove the test data^@ lines, I get about tens of megabytes of heap usage. If I keep those in (longlog2.txt) then I arrive at ~ >700MB heap usage (will confirm the numbers with a release build).<span class="line"><!---->With longlog4.txt (attached) where I remove the test data^@ lines, I get about tens of megabytes of heap usage. If I keep those in (longlog2.txt) then I arrive at ~ &gt;700MB heap usage (will confirm the numbers with a release build).<!----></span><br><br>Removing Blink>Fonts - this seems a case of layout / inline layout / line breaking struggling with the long data dump lines.<span class="line"><!---->Removing Blink&gt;Fonts - this seems a case of layout / inline layout / line breaking struggling with the long data dump lines.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 26<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1178634#c26">Comment 26<!----></a>

        So much thanks to drott@ and futhark@ for their analysis, |AppendPreserveWhitespace| adds a line to StringBuilder at a time in order to mark the forced line break for the line breaker, and the TextNodes are like 64kb.<span class="line"><!---->So much thanks to drott@ and futhark@ for their analysis, |AppendPreserveWhitespace| adds a line to StringBuilder at a time in order to mark the forced line break for the line breaker, and the TextNodes are like 64kb.<!----></span><br><br>We can pre-reserve-capacity to mitigate this, but |StringBuilder::ReserveCapacity| does not reserve actual capacity except for the first call:<span class="line"><!---->We can pre-reserve-capacity to mitigate this, but |StringBuilder::ReserveCapacity| does not reserve actual capacity except for the first call:<!----></span><br>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/wtf/text/string_builder.cc;drc=8cc3cc266b045c4a383cf1725312024e8258e22e;bpv=1;bpt=1;l=138<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/wtf/text/string_builder.cc;drc=8cc3cc266b045c4a383cf1725312024e8258e22e;bpv=1;bpt=1;l=138"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/wtf/text/string_builder.cc;drc=8cc3cc266b045c4a383cf1725312024e8258e22e;bpv=1;bpt=1;l=138<!----></a><br>We'll need to change that.<span class="line"><!---->We'll need to change that.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>

      </div>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1178634#c35">Comment 35<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Mar 5, 2021, 10:35 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1178634#c35">Comment 35<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

          Summary:<strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          2MB binary file (text with U+00 included) eats 4GB of memory in Chrome
          (was: 2MB text file eats 4GB of memory in Chrome)
          <br>
        
          Cc:<strong><!---->Cc:</strong>
          
          bartekn@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          2MB binary file (text with U+00 included) eats 4GB of memory in Chrome
          (was: 2MB text file eats 4GB of memory in Chrome)
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Cc:</strong>
          
          bartekn@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        The fix in <span class="line"><!---->The fix in <!----></span>comment #29<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c29"><!---->comment #29<!----></a> and <span class="line"><!----> and <!----></span>comment #34<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c34"><!---->comment #34<!----></a> fixes excessive reallocations, but the symptom still exists.<span class="line"><!----> fixes excessive reallocations, but the symptom still exists.<!----></span><br><br>Dominik's <span class="line"><!---->Dominik's <!----></span>comment #20<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c20"><!---->comment #20<!----></a> looks like pointing the cause. If I split the reproducing file to:<span class="line"><!----> looks like pointing the cause. If I split the reproducing file to:<!----></span><br>a. The line that contains U+0000<span class="line"><!---->a. The line that contains U+0000<!----></span><br>b. All lines except a.<span class="line"><!---->b. All lines except a.<!----></span><br><br>According to Chrome Task Manager:<span class="line"><!---->According to Chrome Task Manager:<!----></span><br>a is 68kb and consumes 630MB<span class="line"><!---->a is 68kb and consumes 630MB<!----></span><br>b is 660kb and consumes 38MB<span class="line"><!---->b is 660kb and consumes 38MB<!----></span><br><br>So this is probably about handing U+0000 in text files. Updated the summary.<span class="line"><!---->So this is probably about handing U+0000 in text files. Updated the summary.<!----></span><br><br>I tried Visual Studio memory profiler, I'm not a memory expert either but IIUC it can show types only for non-partition-alloc objects. Partition alloc objects still appear in Process Memory, but not in the heap snapshot.<span class="line"><!---->I tried Visual Studio memory profiler, I'm not a memory expert either but IIUC it can show types only for non-partition-alloc objects. Partition alloc objects still appear in Process Memory, but not in the heap snapshot.<!----></span><br><br>I think we need help from memory experts to identify what is consuming the memory. I'll ask at <span class="line"><!---->I think we need help from memory experts to identify what is consuming the memory. I'll ask at <!----></span>crbug.com/1184618<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crbug.com/1184618"><!---->crbug.com/1184618<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        IIRC the code allocates from PartitionAlloc's buffer partition explicitly. You'd have have to replace that with malloc/new. Furthermore, you'd have to disable PartitionAlloc-Everywhere, which intercepts malloc/new and routes to PartitionAlloc -- this is how you can do it<span class="line"><!---->IIRC the code allocates from PartitionAlloc's buffer partition explicitly. You'd have have to replace that with malloc/new. Furthermore, you'd have to disable PartitionAlloc-Everywhere, which intercepts malloc/new and routes to PartitionAlloc -- this is how you can do it<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crrev.com/c/2571140<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/c/2571140"><!---->crrev.com/c/2571140<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span> Like you mentioned, debug builds will disable it automatically (wihtout a need for the CL) but only on Windows. Component builds, will actually do a good job disabling it on all architectures supported so far.<span class="line"><!----> Like you mentioned, debug builds will disable it automatically (wihtout a need for the CL) but only on Windows. Component builds, will actually do a good job disabling it on all architectures supported so far.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1178634#c42">Comment 42<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Mar 8, 2021, 12:42 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        +1 to <span class="line"><!---->+1 to <!----></span>#c40<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c40"><!---->#c40<!----></a> - for decoding to be inflating the data by more than 2x there would need to be a memory leak or some strange decode/encode/decode loop. Possible, but it seems more likely it is downstream from the decode. So... knowing what's in the memory is needed to pinpoint this.<span class="line"><!----> - for decoding to be inflating the data by more than 2x there would need to be a memory leak or some strange decode/encode/decode loop. Possible, but it seems more likely it is downstream from the decode. So... knowing what's in the memory is needed to pinpoint this.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

    <mr-error hidden=""><!----><!----></mr-error>
        
          
       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement. 
      <input id="checkbox" type="checkbox">
      
        <slot></slot>
      <label for="checkbox">
        <slot></slot>
      </label>

            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

        for LitElement.

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          </chops-button>

          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

      UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/88.0.4324.150 Safari/537.36<span class="line"><!---->UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/88.0.4324.150 Safari/537.36<!----></span><br><br>Steps to reproduce the problem:<span class="line"><!---->Steps to reproduce the problem:<!----></span><br>1. Open in Chrome the attached file test.txt which is <2MB<span class="line"><!---->1. Open in Chrome the attached file test.txt which is &lt;2MB<!----></span><br>2. Observe memory usage climbs to 9GB commit, 4GB working set<span class="line"><!---->2. Observe memory usage climbs to 9GB commit, 4GB working set<!----></span><br>3. Scratch your head<span class="line"><!---->3. Scratch your head<!----></span><br><br>What is the expected behavior?<span class="line"><!---->What is the expected behavior?<!----></span><br>Chrome shouldn't eat so much memory.<span class="line"><!---->Chrome shouldn't eat so much memory.<!----></span><br><br>What went wrong?<span class="line"><!---->What went wrong?<!----></span><br>I opened a bunch of CI tabs in raw log format and Windows gave me a low memory notice and random processes started crashing including Chrome.<span class="line"><!---->I opened a bunch of CI tabs in raw log format and Windows gave me a low memory notice and random processes started crashing including Chrome.<!----></span><br><br>Did this work before? N/A <span class="line"><!---->Did this work before? N/A <!----></span><br><br>Chrome version: 88.0.4324.150  Channel: stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome version: 88.0.4324.150  Channel: stable<!----></span><br>OS Version: 6.1 (Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2)<span class="line"><!---->OS Version: 6.1 (Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2)<!----></span><br>Flash Version: <span class="line"><!---->Flash Version: <!----></span><br><br>I was able to reproduce the large memory usage but not the crash from a clean profile. See attached screenshot.<span class="line"><!---->I was able to reproduce the large memory usage but not the crash from a clean profile. See attached screenshot.<!----></span><br><br>The test.txt is a raw log from curl CI builds:<span class="line"><!---->The test.txt is a raw log from curl CI builds:<!----></span><br>https://github.com/curl/curl/runs/1900860438<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/curl/curl/runs/1900860438"><!---->https://github.com/curl/curl/runs/1900860438<!----></a><br>https://dev.azure.com/daniel0244/5571c33c-81e1-43d7-93ee-d3d4152f27b2/_apis/build/builds/4719/logs/110<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://dev.azure.com/daniel0244/5571c33c-81e1-43d7-93ee-d3d4152f27b2/_apis/build/builds/4719/logs/110"><!---->https://dev.azure.com/daniel0244/5571c33c-81e1-43d7-93ee-d3d4152f27b2/_apis/build/builds/4719/logs/110<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Probably you did reproduce, your host or VM just has limited memory that's why it didn't grow so high. I am able to reproduce in Windows 7 and Windows 10 VMs using Chrome/88.0.4324.150. Since the VMs have limited memory the memory usage the usage doesn't grow as high before Chrome and/or some system processes crash. See the animated GIF taken in a windows 7 vm.<span class="line"><!---->Probably you did reproduce, your host or VM just has limited memory that's why it didn't grow so high. I am able to reproduce in Windows 7 and Windows 10 VMs using Chrome/88.0.4324.150. Since the VMs have limited memory the memory usage the usage doesn't grow as high before Chrome and/or some system processes crash. See the animated GIF taken in a windows 7 vm.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        gpu-triage:  I cannot reproduce this locally.  <span class="line"><!---->gpu-triage:  I cannot reproduce this locally.  <!----></span><br><br>For me <span class="line"><!---->For me <!----></span><br>    - Stable: 88.0.4324.182 - caps at 68 MB<span class="line"><!---->    - Stable: 88.0.4324.182 - caps at 68 MB<!----></span><br>    - ToT local build (<span class="line"><!---->    - ToT local build (<!----></span>d93e10683ef83cc4d6b6980440d859a263f8a6c3<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/d93e10683ef83cc4d6b6980440d859a263f8a6c3"><!---->d93e10683ef83cc4d6b6980440d859a263f8a6c3<!----></a>) - caps at 145 MB<span class="line"><!---->) - caps at 145 MB<!----></span><br><br>Could the reporter or swarnasree.mukkala@ check their chrome://gpu/ and paste the results here. There is one for metrics[1], but it scales with number of submitted frames, not size of the page.<span class="line"><!----> there is no cc/ change that affects painting in that range.         I checked, the file has all of its text in a giant <pre> element, so the html tree size is actually very small. I logged this locally and the visible_objects is 1, so this does not appear to be from TextPaintTimingDetector. FWIW I do see 2GB memory footprint.<span class="line"><!---->I checked, the file has all of its text in a giant &lt;pre&gt; element, so the html tree size is actually very small. I logged this locally and the visible_objects is 1, so this does not appear to be from TextPaintTimingDetector. FWIW I do see 2GB memory footprint.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        On Windows, using Visual Studio heap debugging and taking snapshots for a 10 line excerpt of the log file, then loading a longer version that contains the first block of "test data^@test data...", it seems like private bytes increases, but the actual heap snapshot difference between two snapshots is not that big. I am not an expert at memory debugging but this may mean that there have been a lot of temporary allocations trying to line break the "test data^@" blocks?" (and this is a build with partition_alloc enabled, so visual studio's insight into what's happening with the allocations may be limited).<span class="line"><!---->On Windows, using Visual Studio heap debugging and taking snapshots for a 10 line excerpt of the log file, then loading a longer version that contains the first block of "test data^@test data...", it seems like private bytes increases, but the actual heap snapshot difference between two snapshots is not that big. I am not an expert at memory debugging but this may mean that there have been a lot of temporary allocations trying to line break the "test data^@" blocks?" (and this is a build with partition_alloc enabled, so visual studio's insight into what's happening with the allocations may be limited).<!----></span><br><br>Between the heap snapshots, most of the allocations (third column, bytes) are in:<span class="line"><!---->Between the heap snapshots, most of the allocations (third column, bytes) are in:<!----></span><br>cc::ProxyMain::BeginMainFrame	77,462	9,047,361	cc.dll<span class="line"><!---->cc::ProxyMain::BeginMainFrame	77,462	9,047,361	cc.dll<!----></span><br>cc::LayerTreeHost::RequestMainFrameUpdate	62,881	6,921,069	cc.dll<span class="line"><!---->cc::LayerTreeHost::RequestMainFrameUpdate	62,881	6,921,069	cc.dll<!----></span><br>cc::LayerTreeHost::BeginMainFrame	14,560	2,024,744	cc.dll<span class="line"><!---->cc::LayerTreeHost::BeginMainFrame	14,560	2,024,744	cc.dll<!----></span><br><br>Which in itself does not look excessive. <span class="line"><!---->Which in itself does not look excessive. <!----></span><br><br>A second important observation: I see a big difference in heap memory consumption if I create a log file where I remove the test data^@ lines. <span class="line"><!---->A second important observation: I see a big difference in heap memory consumption if I create a log file where I remove the test data^@ lines. <!----></span><br><br>With longlog4.txt (attached) where I remove the test data^@ lines, I get about tens of megabytes of heap usage. If I keep those in (longlog2.txt) then I arrive at ~ >700MB heap usage (will confirm the numbers with a release build).<span class="line"><!---->With longlog4.txt (attached) where I remove the test data^@ lines, I get about tens of megabytes of heap usage. If I keep those in (longlog2.txt) then I arrive at ~ &gt;700MB heap usage (will confirm the numbers with a release build).<!----></span><br><br>Removing Blink>Fonts - this seems a case of layout / inline layout / line breaking struggling with the long data dump lines.<span class="line"><!---->Removing Blink&gt;Fonts - this seems a case of layout / inline layout / line breaking struggling with the long data dump lines.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        So much thanks to drott@ and futhark@ for their analysis, |AppendPreserveWhitespace| adds a line to StringBuilder at a time in order to mark the forced line break for the line breaker, and the TextNodes are like 64kb.<span class="line"><!---->So much thanks to drott@ and futhark@ for their analysis, |AppendPreserveWhitespace| adds a line to StringBuilder at a time in order to mark the forced line break for the line breaker, and the TextNodes are like 64kb.<!----></span><br><br>We can pre-reserve-capacity to mitigate this, but |StringBuilder::ReserveCapacity| does not reserve actual capacity except for the first call:<span class="line"><!---->We can pre-reserve-capacity to mitigate this, but |StringBuilder::ReserveCapacity| does not reserve actual capacity except for the first call:<!----></span><br>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/wtf/text/string_builder.cc;drc=8cc3cc266b045c4a383cf1725312024e8258e22e;bpv=1;bpt=1;l=138<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/wtf/text/string_builder.cc;drc=8cc3cc266b045c4a383cf1725312024e8258e22e;bpv=1;bpt=1;l=138"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/wtf/text/string_builder.cc;drc=8cc3cc266b045c4a383cf1725312024e8258e22e;bpv=1;bpt=1;l=138<!----></a><br>We'll need to change that.<span class="line"><!---->We'll need to change that.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

          Summary:<strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          2MB binary file (text with U+00 included) eats 4GB of memory in Chrome
          (was: 2MB text file eats 4GB of memory in Chrome)
          <br>
        
          Cc:<strong><!---->Cc:</strong>
          
          bartekn@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          2MB binary file (text with U+00 included) eats 4GB of memory in Chrome
          (was: 2MB text file eats 4GB of memory in Chrome)
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Cc:</strong>
          
          bartekn@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        The fix in <span class="line"><!---->The fix in <!----></span>comment #29<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c29"><!---->comment #29<!----></a> and <span class="line"><!----> and <!----></span>comment #34<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c34"><!---->comment #34<!----></a> fixes excessive reallocations, but the symptom still exists.<span class="line"><!----> fixes excessive reallocations, but the symptom still exists.<!----></span><br><br>Dominik's <span class="line"><!---->Dominik's <!----></span>comment #20<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c20"><!---->comment #20<!----></a> looks like pointing the cause. If I split the reproducing file to:<span class="line"><!----> looks like pointing the cause. If I split the reproducing file to:<!----></span><br>a. The line that contains U+0000<span class="line"><!---->a. The line that contains U+0000<!----></span><br>b. All lines except a.<span class="line"><!---->b. All lines except a.<!----></span><br><br>According to Chrome Task Manager:<span class="line"><!---->According to Chrome Task Manager:<!----></span><br>a is 68kb and consumes 630MB<span class="line"><!---->a is 68kb and consumes 630MB<!----></span><br>b is 660kb and consumes 38MB<span class="line"><!---->b is 660kb and consumes 38MB<!----></span><br><br>So this is probably about handing U+0000 in text files. Updated the summary.<span class="line"><!---->So this is probably about handing U+0000 in text files. Updated the summary.<!----></span><br><br>I tried Visual Studio memory profiler, I'm not a memory expert either but IIUC it can show types only for non-partition-alloc objects. Partition alloc objects still appear in Process Memory, but not in the heap snapshot.<span class="line"><!---->I tried Visual Studio memory profiler, I'm not a memory expert either but IIUC it can show types only for non-partition-alloc objects. Partition alloc objects still appear in Process Memory, but not in the heap snapshot.<!----></span><br><br>I think we need help from memory experts to identify what is consuming the memory. I'll ask at <span class="line"><!---->I think we need help from memory experts to identify what is consuming the memory. I'll ask at <!----></span>crbug.com/1184618<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crbug.com/1184618"><!---->crbug.com/1184618<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1178634#c36">Comment 36<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Mar 8, 2021, 3:59 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>

        The difference is not only in whether it has the U+0000 character - what happens if you replace that with 'a', for example? - but also in file a) having very long lines b) not having particularly long lines. I was trying to look if there's a way to disable partition_alloc - looks like debug builds may let allocations show through, but I am not sure.<span class="line"><!---->The difference is not only in whether it has the U+0000 character - what happens if you replace that with 'a', for example? - but also in file a) having very long lines b) not having particularly long lines. I was trying to look if there's a way to disable partition_alloc - looks like debug builds may let allocations show through, but I am not sure.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 37<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1178634#c37">Comment 37<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      bartekn@chromium.org<a id="user-link" href="/u/2349335196" title="bartekn@chromium.org"><!---->bartekn@chromium.org<!----></a>
      bartekn@chromium.org<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->bartekn@chromium.org<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        
      Mon, Mar 8, 2021, 5:29 AM EST
    <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Mar 8, 2021, 5:29 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1178634#c37">Comment 37<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Mar 8, 2021, 5:29 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1178634#c37">Comment 37<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Mar 8, 2021, 5:29 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        IIRC the code allocates from PartitionAlloc's buffer partition explicitly. You'd have have to replace that with malloc/new. Furthermore, you'd have to disable PartitionAlloc-Everywhere, which intercepts malloc/new and routes to PartitionAlloc -- this is how you can do it<span class="line"><!---->IIRC the code allocates from PartitionAlloc's buffer partition explicitly. You'd have have to replace that with malloc/new. Furthermore, you'd have to disable PartitionAlloc-Everywhere, which intercepts malloc/new and routes to PartitionAlloc -- this is how you can do it<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crrev.com/c/2571140<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/c/2571140"><!---->crrev.com/c/2571140<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span> Like you mentioned, debug builds will disable it automatically (wihtout a need for the CL) but only on Windows. Component builds, will actually do a good job disabling it on all architectures supported so far.<span class="line"><!----> Like you mentioned, debug builds will disable it automatically (wihtout a need for the CL) but only on Windows. Component builds, will actually do a good job disabling it on all architectures supported so far.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        Did one more test; took the "file with U+00" and replaced all "U+00" with "X"; i.e.;<span class="line"><!---->Did one more test; took the "file with U+00" and replaced all "U+00" with "X"; i.e.;<!----></span><br>% tr '\000' X < large-text-1178634-line-with-00.txt > large-text-1178634-line-with-00-replaced-with-X.txt<span class="line"><!---->% tr '\000' X &lt; large-text-1178634-line-with-00.txt &gt; large-text-1178634-line-with-00-replaced-with-X.txt<!----></span><br><br>line-with-00: 630MB<span class="line"><!---->line-with-00: 630MB<!----></span><br>replaced-with-X: 21MB<span class="line"><!---->replaced-with-X: 21MB<!----></span><br><br>So, <span class="line"><!---->So, <!----></span>comment #3<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c3"><!---->comment #3<!----></a> indicates this is about defragmentation/compaction of the heap memory.<span class="line"><!----> indicates this is about defragmentation/compaction of the heap memory.<!----></span><br><br>But this test also indicates that there's something with handling U+00, either keeping more memory, or doing more temporary alloc/delete, when the input file has U+00.<span class="line"><!---->But this test also indicates that there's something with handling U+00, either keeping more memory, or doing more temporary alloc/delete, when the input file has U+00.<!----></span><br><br>Haven't identified which of it, or where it is.<span class="line"><!---->Haven't identified which of it, or where it is.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        One more test; because U+00 is replaced with U+FFFD at some point (loader or DOM, not sure), this text requires 16 bits string.<span class="line"><!---->One more test; because U+00 is replaced with U+FFFD at some point (loader or DOM, not sure), this text requires 16 bits string.<!----></span><br><br>Attached a test file that replaced "X" with a CJK character, which should upgrade the string to 16 bits.<span class="line"><!---->Attached a test file that replaced "X" with a CJK character, which should upgrade the string to 16 bits.<!----></span><br><br>line-with-00: 630MB<span class="line"><!---->line-with-00: 630MB<!----></span><br>replaced-with-X: 21MB<span class="line"><!---->replaced-with-X: 21MB<!----></span><br>replaced-with-Kana: 310MB<span class="line"><!---->replaced-with-Kana: 310MB<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

            Issue 1178634: 2MB binary file (text with U+00 included) eats 4GB of memory in Chrome
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1178634: 2MB binary file (text with U+00 included) eats 4GB of memory in Chrome
          </h1>
          
            Reported by
            
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>
      term...@gmail.com<a id="user-link" href="/u/1418409828" title="term...@gmail.com"><!---->term...@gmail.com<!----></a>
      term...@gmail.com<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->term...@gmail.com<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>
    <mr-user-link aria-label="issue reporter"></mr-user-link>
            on 
      Mon, Feb 15, 2021, 3:41 PM EST
    <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Feb 15, 2021, 3:41 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
            
          <small class="byline">
            Reported by
            <mr-user-link aria-label="issue reporter"></mr-user-link>
            on <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Feb 15, 2021, 3:41 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
            
          </small>
        <div class="main-text">
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1178634: 2MB binary file (text with U+00 included) eats 4GB of memory in Chrome
          </h1>
          <small class="byline">
            Reported by
            <mr-user-link aria-label="issue reporter"></mr-user-link>
            on <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Feb 15, 2021, 3:41 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
            
          </small>
        </div>

      UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/88.0.4324.150 Safari/537.36<span class="line"><!---->UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/88.0.4324.150 Safari/537.36<!----></span><br><br>Steps to reproduce the problem:<span class="line"><!---->Steps to reproduce the problem:<!----></span><br>1. Open in Chrome the attached file test.txt which is <2MB<span class="line"><!---->1. Open in Chrome the attached file test.txt which is &lt;2MB<!----></span><br>2. Observe memory usage climbs to 9GB commit, 4GB working set<span class="line"><!---->2. Observe memory usage climbs to 9GB commit, 4GB working set<!----></span><br>3. Scratch your head<span class="line"><!---->3. Scratch your head<!----></span><br><br>What is the expected behavior?<span class="line"><!---->What is the expected behavior?<!----></span><br>Chrome shouldn't eat so much memory.<span class="line"><!---->Chrome shouldn't eat so much memory.<!----></span><br><br>What went wrong?<span class="line"><!---->What went wrong?<!----></span><br>I opened a bunch of CI tabs in raw log format and Windows gave me a low memory notice and random processes started crashing including Chrome.<span class="line"><!---->I opened a bunch of CI tabs in raw log format and Windows gave me a low memory notice and random processes started crashing including Chrome.<!----></span><br><br>Did this work before? N/A <span class="line"><!---->Did this work before? N/A <!----></span><br><br>Chrome version: 88.0.4324.150  Channel: stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome version: 88.0.4324.150  Channel: stable<!----></span><br>OS Version: 6.1 (Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2)<span class="line"><!---->OS Version: 6.1 (Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2)<!----></span><br>Flash Version: <span class="line"><!---->Flash Version: <!----></span><br><br>I was able to reproduce the large memory usage but not the crash from a clean profile. See attached screenshot.<span class="line"><!---->I was able to reproduce the large memory usage but not the crash from a clean profile. See attached screenshot.<!----></span><br><br>The test.txt is a raw log from curl CI builds:<span class="line"><!---->The test.txt is a raw log from curl CI builds:<!----></span><br>https://github.com/curl/curl/runs/1900860438<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/curl/curl/runs/1900860438"><!---->https://github.com/curl/curl/runs/1900860438<!----></a><br>https://dev.azure.com/daniel0244/5571c33c-81e1-43d7-93ee-d3d4152f27b2/_apis/build/builds/4719/logs/110<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://dev.azure.com/daniel0244/5571c33c-81e1-43d7-93ee-d3d4152f27b2/_apis/build/builds/4719/logs/110"><!---->https://dev.azure.com/daniel0244/5571c33c-81e1-43d7-93ee-d3d4152f27b2/_apis/build/builds/4719/logs/110<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Tested the issue on reported chrome version #88.0.4324.150 using Windows 10. Observed that memory usage did not grow up-to 9GB.<span class="line"><!---->Tested the issue on reported chrome version #88.0.4324.150 using Windows 10. Observed that memory usage did not grow up-to 9GB.<!----></span><br>Attached screenshot for reference.<span class="line"><!---->Attached screenshot for reference.<!----></span><br><br>@reporter: Could you please review attached screenshot and let us know if anything is missed from our end. Retry the issue on a new profile without any apps and extensions in it, reset all flags to default and let us know if issue still exits.<span class="line"><!---->@reporter: Could you please review attached screenshot and let us know if anything is missed from our end. Retry the issue on a new profile without any apps and extensions in it, reset all flags to default and let us know if issue still exits.<!----></span><br>Thanks.!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks.!<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Feb 16, 2021, 2:17 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Probably you did reproduce, your host or VM just has limited memory that's why it didn't grow so high. I am able to reproduce in Windows 7 and Windows 10 VMs using Chrome/88.0.4324.150. Since the VMs have limited memory the memory usage the usage doesn't grow as high before Chrome and/or some system processes crash. See the animated GIF taken in a windows 7 vm.<span class="line"><!---->Probably you did reproduce, your host or VM just has limited memory that's why it didn't grow so high. I am able to reproduce in Windows 7 and Windows 10 VMs using Chrome/88.0.4324.150. Since the VMs have limited memory the memory usage the usage doesn't grow as high before Chrome and/or some system processes crash. See the animated GIF taken in a windows 7 vm.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        npm@, tdresser@, in order to know whether it's related to LCP, it would be useful to log whether these two data structures explode when the memory surges.<span class="line"><!---->npm@, tdresser@, in order to know whether it's related to LCP, it would be useful to log whether these two data structures explode when the memory surges.<!----></span><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/core/paint/text_paint_timing_detector.h;l=117;drc=0cf3ae8180a6ed761609f2907b59124e366e41b9<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/core/paint/text_paint_timing_detector.h;l=117;drc=0cf3ae8180a6ed761609f2907b59124e366e41b9"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/core/paint/text_paint_timing_detector.h;l=117;drc=0cf3ae8180a6ed761609f2907b59124e366e41b9<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I checked, the file has all of its text in a giant <pre> element, so the html tree size is actually very small. FWIW I do see 2GB memory footprint.<span class="line"><!---->I checked, the file has all of its text in a giant &lt;pre&gt; element, so the html tree size is actually very small.         by

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1178634#c20">Comment 20<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 2, 2021, 9:48 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1178634#c20">Comment 20<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Mar 2, 2021, 9:48 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        On Windows, using Visual Studio heap debugging and taking snapshots for a 10 line excerpt of the log file, then loading a longer version that contains the first block of "test data^@test data...", it seems like private bytes increases, but the actual heap snapshot difference between two snapshots is not that big. I am not an expert at memory debugging but this may mean that there have been a lot of temporary allocations trying to line break the "test data^@" blocks?" (and this is a build with partition_alloc enabled, so visual studio's insight into what's happening with the allocations may be limited).<span class="line"><!---->On Windows, using Visual Studio heap debugging and taking snapshots for a 10 line excerpt of the log file, then loading a longer version that contains the first block of "test data^@test data...", it seems like private bytes increases, but the actual heap snapshot difference between two snapshots is not that big. I am not an expert at memory debugging but this may mean that there have been a lot of temporary allocations trying to line break the "test data^@" blocks?" (and this is a build with partition_alloc enabled, so visual studio's insight into what's happening with the allocations may be limited).<!----></span><br><br>Between the heap snapshots, most of the allocations (third column, bytes) are in:<span class="line"><!---->Between the heap snapshots, most of the allocations (third column, bytes) are in:<!----></span><br>cc::ProxyMain::BeginMainFrame	77,462	9,047,361	cc.dll<span class="line"><!---->cc::ProxyMain::BeginMainFrame	77,462	9,047,361	cc.dll<!----></span><br>cc::LayerTreeHost::RequestMainFrameUpdate	62,881	6,921,069	cc.dll<span class="line"><!---->cc::LayerTreeHost::RequestMainFrameUpdate	62,881	6,921,069	cc.dll<!----></span><br>cc::LayerTreeHost::BeginMainFrame	14,560	2,024,744	cc.dll<span class="line"><!---->cc::LayerTreeHost::BeginMainFrame	14,560	2,024,744	cc.dll<!----></span><br><br>Which in itself does not look excessive. <span class="line"><!---->Which in itself does not look excessive. <!----></span><br><br>A second important observation: I see a big difference in heap memory consumption if I create a log file where I remove the test data^@ lines. <span class="line"><!---->A second important observation: I see a big difference in heap memory consumption if I create a log file where I remove the test data^@ lines. <!----></span><br><br>With longlog4.txt (attached) where I remove the test data^@ lines, I get about tens of megabytes of heap usage. If I keep those in (longlog2.txt) then I arrive at ~ >700MB heap usage (will confirm the numbers with a release build).<span class="line"><!---->With longlog4.txt (attached) where I remove the test data^@ lines, I get about tens of megabytes of heap usage. If I keep those in (longlog2.txt) then I arrive at ~ &gt;700MB heap usage (will confirm the numbers with a release build).<!----></span><br><br>Removing Blink>Fonts - this seems a case of layout / inline layout / line breaking struggling with the long data dump lines.<span class="line"><!---->Removing Blink&gt;Fonts - this seems a case of layout / inline layout / line breaking struggling with the long data dump lines.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        So much thanks to drott@ and futhark@ for their analysis, |AppendPreserveWhitespace| adds a line to StringBuilder at a time in order to mark the forced line break for the line breaker, and the TextNodes are like 64kb.<span class="line"><!---->So much thanks to drott@ and futhark@ for their analysis, |AppendPreserveWhitespace| adds a line to StringBuilder at a time in order to mark the forced line break for the line breaker, and the TextNodes are like 64kb.<!----></span><br><br>We can pre-reserve-capacity to mitigate this, but |StringBuilder::ReserveCapacity| does not reserve actual capacity except for the first call:<span class="line"><!---->We can pre-reserve-capacity to mitigate this, but |StringBuilder::ReserveCapacity| does not reserve actual capacity except for the first call:<!----></span><br>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/wtf/text/string_builder.cc;drc=8cc3cc266b045c4a383cf1725312024e8258e22e;bpv=1;bpt=1;l=138<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/wtf/text/string_builder.cc;drc=8cc3cc266b045c4a383cf1725312024e8258e22e;bpv=1;bpt=1;l=138"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/master:third_party/blink/renderer/platform/wtf/text/string_builder.cc;drc=8cc3cc266b045c4a383cf1725312024e8258e22e;bpv=1;bpt=1;l=138<!----></a><br>We'll need to change that.<span class="line"><!---->We'll need to change that.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/7afda0e65468afa2f59a4ef2990c953c08145141<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/7afda0e65468afa2f59a4ef2990c953c08145141"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/7afda0e65468afa2f59a4ef2990c953c08145141<!----></a><br><br>commit <span class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>7afda0e65468afa2f59a4ef2990c953c08145141<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/7afda0e65468afa2f59a4ef2990c953c08145141"><!---->7afda0e65468afa2f59a4ef2990c953c08145141<!----></a><br>Author: Koji Ishii <<span class="line"><!---->Author: Koji Ishii &lt;<!----></span>kojii@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:kojii@chromium.org"><!---->kojii@chromium.org<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Wed Mar 03 19:31:10 2021<span class="line"><!---->Date: Wed Mar 03 19:31:10 2021<!----></span><br><br>Enable |StringBuilder::ReserveCapacity| when the buffer exists<span class="line"><!---->Enable |StringBuilder::ReserveCapacity| when the buffer exists<!----></span><br><br>It turned out that |StringBuilder::ReserveCapacity| does the<span class="line"><!---->It turned out that |StringBuilder::ReserveCapacity| does the<!----></span><br>work only if the buffer does not exist. This patch:<span class="line"><!---->work only if the buffer does not exist. This patch:<!----></span><br>1. Enables it when the buffer exists.<span class="line"><!---->1. Enables it when the buffer exists.<!----></span><br>2. Adds |Ensure16Bit(unsigned new_capacity)| to avoid double<span class="line"><!---->2. Adds |Ensure16Bit(unsigned new_capacity)| to avoid double<!----></span><br>   reallocations when 8 bits buffer exists.<span class="line"><!---->   reallocations when 8 bits buffer exists.<!----></span><br><br>Also reviewed all calls to this function. All callers call<span class="line"><!---->Also reviewed all calls to this function. All callers call<!----></span><br>it only once, right after the construction, except<span class="line"><!---->it only once, right after the construction, except<!----></span><br>|NGInlineItemsBuilder|. This patch includes the change to the<span class="line"><!---->|NGInlineItemsBuilder|. This patch includes the change to the<!----></span><br>only caller to leverage the new capability.<span class="line"><!---->only caller to leverage the new capability.<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1178634<span class="line"><!---->Bug: 1178634<!----></span><br>Change-Id: I94e520bf09a96088e83feac76f724e8c19fddb24<span class="line"><!---->Change-Id: I94e520bf09a96088e83feac76f724e8c19fddb24<!----></span><br>Reviewed-on: <span class="line"><!---->Reviewed-on: <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2732208<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2732208"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/2732208<!----></a><br>Auto-Submit: Koji Ishii <<span ~37%.<span class="line"><!---->This patch recovers the perf test by ~37%.<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1184502<span class="line"><!---->Bug: 1184502<!----></span>, <span class="line"><!---->,           Summary:<strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          2MB binary file (text with U+00 included) eats 4GB of memory in Chrome
          (was: 2MB text file eats 4GB of memory in Chrome)
          <br>
        
          Cc:<strong><!---->Cc:</strong>
          
          bartekn@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Summary:</strong>
          
          2MB binary file (text with U+00 included) eats 4GB of memory in Chrome
          (was: 2MB text file eats 4GB of memory in Chrome)
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Cc:</strong>
          
          bartekn@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        The fix in <span class="line"><!---->The fix in <!----></span>comment #29<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c29"><!---->comment #29<!----></a> and <span class="line"><!----> and <!----></span>comment #34<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c34"><!---->comment #34<!----></a> fixes excessive reallocations, but the symptom still exists.<span class="line"><!----> fixes excessive reallocations, but the symptom still exists.<!----></span><br><br>Dominik's <span class="line"><!---->Dominik's <!----></span>comment #20<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c20"><!---->comment #20<!----></a> looks like pointing the cause. If I split the reproducing file to:<span class="line"><!----> looks like pointing the cause. If I split the reproducing file to:<!----></span><br>a. The line that contains U+0000<span class="line"><!---->a. The line that contains U+0000<!----></span><br>b. All lines except a.<span class="line"><!---->b. All lines except a.<!----></span><br><br>According to Chrome Task Manager:<span class="line"><!---->According to Chrome Task Manager:<!----></span><br>a is 68kb and consumes 630MB<span class="line"><!---->a is 68kb and consumes 630MB<!----></span><br>b is 660kb and consumes 38MB<span class="line"><!---->b is 660kb and consumes 38MB<!----></span><br><br>So this is probably about handing U+0000 in text files. Updated the summary.<span class="line"><!---->So this is probably about handing U+0000 in text files. Updated the summary.<!----></span><br><br>I tried Visual Studio memory profiler, I'm not a memory expert either but IIUC it can show types only for non-partition-alloc objects. Partition alloc objects still appear in Process Memory, but not in the heap snapshot.<span class="line"><!---->I tried Visual Studio memory profiler, I'm not a memory expert either but IIUC it can show types only for non-partition-alloc objects. Partition alloc objects still appear in Process Memory, but not in the heap snapshot.<!----></span><br><br>I think we need help from memory experts to identify what is consuming the memory. I'll ask at <span class="line"><!---->I think we need help from memory experts to identify what is consuming the memory. I'll ask at <!----></span>crbug.com/1184618<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crbug.com/1184618"><!---->crbug.com/1184618<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The difference is not only in whether it has the U+0000 character - what happens if you replace that with 'a', for example? - but also in file a) having very long lines b) not having particularly long lines. I was trying to look if there's a way to disable partition_alloc - looks like debug builds may let allocations show through, but I am not sure.<span class="line"><!---->The difference is not only in whether it has the U+0000 character - what happens if you replace that with 'a', for example? - but also in file a) having very long lines b) not having particularly long lines. I was trying to look if there's a way to disable partition_alloc - looks like debug builds may let allocations show through, but I am not sure.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

      bartekn@chromium.org<span id="user-text" hidden=""><!---->bartekn@chromium.org<!----></span>
      <div id="availability-text" class="availability-notice" title="undefined" hidden=""><!----><!----></div>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1178634#c37">Comment 37<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Mar 8, 2021, 5:29 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1178634#c37">Comment 37<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Mar 8, 2021, 5:29 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        IIRC the code allocates from PartitionAlloc's buffer partition explicitly. You'd have have to replace that with malloc/new. Furthermore, you'd have to disable PartitionAlloc-Everywhere, which intercepts malloc/new and routes to PartitionAlloc -- this is how you can do it<span class="line"><!---->IIRC the code allocates from PartitionAlloc's buffer partition explicitly. You'd have have to replace that with malloc/new. Furthermore, you'd have to disable PartitionAlloc-Everywhere, which intercepts malloc/new and routes to PartitionAlloc -- this is how you can do it<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crrev.com/c/2571140<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/c/2571140"><!---->crrev.com/c/2571140<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span> Like you mentioned, debug builds will disable it automatically (wihtout a need for the CL) but only on Windows. Component builds, will actually do a good job disabling it on all architectures supported so far.<span class="line"><!----> Like you mentioned, debug builds will disable it automatically (wihtout a need for the CL) but only on Windows. Component builds, will actually do a good job disabling it on all architectures supported so far.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Did one more test; took the "file with U+00" and replaced all "U+00" with "X"; i.e.;<span class="line"><!---->Did one more test; took the "file with U+00" and replaced all "U+00" with "X"; i.e.;<!----></span><br>% tr '\000' X < large-text-1178634-line-with-00.txt > large-text-1178634-line-with-00-replaced-with-X.txt<span class="line"><!---->% tr '\000' X &lt; large-text-1178634-line-with-00.txt &gt; large-text-1178634-line-with-00-replaced-with-X.txt<!----></span><br><br>line-with-00: 630MB<span class="line"><!---->line-with-00: 630MB<!----></span><br>replaced-with-X: 21MB<span class="line"><!---->replaced-with-X: 21MB<!----></span><br><br>So, <span class="line"><!---->So, <!----></span>comment #3<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c3"><!---->comment #3<!----></a> indicates this is about defragmentation/compaction of the heap memory.<span class="line"><!----> indicates this is about defragmentation/compaction of the heap memory.<!----></span><br><br>But this test also indicates that there's something with handling U+00, either keeping more memory, or doing more temporary alloc/delete, when the input file has U+00.<span class="line"><!---->But this test also indicates that there's something with handling U+00, either keeping more memory, or doing more temporary alloc/delete, when the input file has U+00.<!----></span><br><br>Haven't identified which of it, or where it is.<span class="line"><!---->Haven't identified which of it, or where it is.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        <chops-timestamp title="Mon, Mar 8, 2021, 9:20 AM EST"></chops-timestamp>
